resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.
resolution.name: Fixed

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.
status.name: Resolved

pitrou commented on pull request #5514: ARROW-6701: [C++][R] Lint failing on R cpp code
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/5514#discussion_r328732600
 
 

 ##########
 File path: r/lint.sh
 ##########
 @@ -17,11 +17,14 @@
 # specific language governing permissions and limitations
 # under the License.
 
+# This script requires Python 3 and clang-format, which should already be
+# on your system.
+
 SOURCE_DIR="$( cd "$( dirname "${BASH_SOURCE[0]}" )" && pwd )"
 CPP_BUILD_SUPPORT=$SOURCE_DIR/../cpp/build-support
 
 # Run clang-format
-CLANG_FORMAT=clang-format-7
+CLANG_FORMAT=$(which clang-format)
 
 Review comment:
   Hmm, it is very recommended to stick to `clang-format-7`, because different versions can produce different formatting (and then CI fails).
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.
 
For queries about this service, please contact Infrastructure at:
users@infra.apache.org

nealrichardson commented on pull request #5514: ARROW-6701: [C++][R] Lint failing on R cpp code
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/5514#discussion_r328750259
 
 

 ##########
 File path: r/lint.sh
 ##########
 @@ -17,11 +17,14 @@
 # specific language governing permissions and limitations
 # under the License.
 
+# This script requires Python 3 and clang-format, which should already be
+# on your system.
+
 SOURCE_DIR="$( cd "$( dirname "${BASH_SOURCE[0]}" )" && pwd )"
 CPP_BUILD_SUPPORT=$SOURCE_DIR/../cpp/build-support
 
 # Run clang-format
-CLANG_FORMAT=clang-format-7
+CLANG_FORMAT=$(which clang-format)
 
 Review comment:
   The script failed for me locally because it said there was no such command, and I couldn't find any docs on how to obtain this or any other prerequisites for the script. But this worked and also worked on Travis on my fork. 
   
   If it needs to be clang-format-7, can we either (1) provide instructions on how to get it, and/or (2) maybe do like
   
   ```
   if [ "$CLANG_FORMAT" == "]; then
     CLANG_FORMAT=$(which clang-format)
   fi
   ```
   
   for a default, and then set that env var in the Travis job?
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.
 
For queries about this service, please contact Infrastructure at:
users@infra.apache.org

 # specific language governing permissions and limitations

+# on your system.

 SOURCE_DIR="$( cd "$( dirname "${BASH_SOURCE[0]}" )" && pwd )"
 CPP_BUILD_SUPPORT=$SOURCE_DIR/../cpp/build-support
 
 # Run clang-format
-CLANG_FORMAT=clang-format-7
+CLANG_FORMAT=$(which clang-format)
 
 Review comment:
   It needs to be the same well-defined version of clang-format accross all scripts (CI, etc.). If we want to switch to version 8 or something, we'll need to do it everywhere.
   
   I don't understand your (2) proposal. You would still have the problem that it does a different format than CI does.
 
----------------------------------------------------------------

kou commented on pull request #5514: ARROW-6701: [C++][R] Lint failing on R cpp code
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/5514#discussion_r328848065
 
 

 ##########
 File path: r/lint.sh
 ##########
 @@ -17,11 +17,14 @@
 # specific language governing permissions and limitations
 # under the License.
 
+# This script requires Python 3 and clang-format, which should already be
+# on your system.
+
 SOURCE_DIR="$( cd "$( dirname "${BASH_SOURCE[0]}" )" && pwd )"
 CPP_BUILD_SUPPORT=$SOURCE_DIR/../cpp/build-support
 
 # Run clang-format
-CLANG_FORMAT=clang-format-7
+CLANG_FORMAT=$(which clang-format)
 
 Review comment:
   How about `: ${CLANG_FORMAT:=clang-format-7}` for local run on macOS?
   We can run `CLANG_FORMAT=$(which clang-format) ./lint.sh` on macOS with the same `lint.sh`.
   
   BTW, if you install LLVM by Homebrew, `CLANG_FORMAT=$(brew --prefix llvm@7)/bin/clang-format ./lint.sh` is better.
 
----------------------------------------------------------------

URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/5514#discussion_r329062866
 
 

 ##########
 File path: r/README.Rmd
 ##########
 @@ -161,6 +161,26 @@ remotes::install_github("romainfrancois/decor")
 install.packages(c("dplyr", "purrr", "glue"))
 ```
 
+We use Google C++ style in our C++ code. Check for style errors with
+
+```
+./lint.sh
+```
+
+Fix any style issues before committing with
+
+```
+./lint.sh --fix
+```
+
+The lint script requires Python 3 and `clang-format`. If the command isn't
+found, you can explicitly provide the path to it like
+`CLANG_FORMAT=$(which clang-format) ./lint.sh`
+
+For consistency, it is recommended that you use `clang-format-7`. On macOS,
 
 Review comment:
   The issue is more serious than that. The behavior of clang-format changes slightly from LLVM major version to major version, so people _need_ to use clang-format-7

issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

fields.summary: [C++][R] Lint failing on R cpp code

comments.body: This seems to be passing on master now; was it already fixed? [https://travis-ci.org/apache/arrow/jobs/589914595]

The strange thing is I don't think it ever failed on master.  I only discovered it when creating release branches.  It might be an issue with sliding past CI at some point and no-one has touched the file?
¯\_(ツ)_/¯ I'll try to reproduce and fix locally
thanks downgrading from blocker since it doesn't seem to actually happening on master and isn't blocking the release.
